Description: Lower body sherd of Attic black-figured pottery closed vessel, possibly a neck-amphora; exterior: black-figure decoration consisting of winged figure, probably a siren (chest with added red, part of tail, and legs remaining), to right; below, triple dot band, narrow black band, and parts of two rays; blob and incised blob rosette as filling ornament.
Producer name: Attributed to: The Polos Painter (Companion of)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 480, no. B835)
Venit 1984 / Early Attic Black Figure Vases in Egypt (p. 151, fig. 19)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0017) (Phase 1)
